children.name: all through a priod of time
all day/ all morning/ all week etc
time
children.definition: /taɪm/  a time when someone does something or something happens -- use this especially to talk about something that happensmorethanonce:
examples: ▪ do you remember that time tim got really drunk at sarah’s party?
▪ play it really loud this time.
the only/same/last etc time
▪ the last time we ate meat was at thanksgiving.
▪ the only time i’ve seen him with a girl was that party at mike’s place.
▪ give us a call next time you’re in town.
▪ that was around the same time that i met linda.
the first/second/third etc time
▪ is this the first time you’ve played pool?
▪ sandra, that’s the third time i’ve asked you to keep quiet.
▪ alex won the 100 metres for the fifth time in a row he won five times, and no one else won the race in between.
four/six/several etc times
▪ this is my favourite film - i’ve seen it five times.
▪ it’s silly -- i’ve met him several times, but i can never remember his name.
a number of timesformal use this to say something happened several times
▪ she’s been to greece a number of times.
▪ i’ve heard jessie play a number of times, and i think he’s great.
every/each time
▪ every time i met her, she asked me about the children.
time when
▪ do you remember the time when dad lost the car keys?

children.name: occasion
children.definition: /əˈkeɪʒən/ formala time when something happens:
examples: dịp
on one/that etc occasion
▪ the witness said that on both occasions he noticed davis because of his heavily tattooed arms.
▪ on one occasion, anna fainted while out shopping with friends.
▪ she had met zahid on a previous occasion.
on numerous/several occasionsuse this to emphasize that something happened many times : nhiều dịp
▪ i’ve suggested that she should move on numerous occasions, but she never takes any notice.
▪ i remember michael sleeping in your room on several occasions and mom not knowing about it.

children.name: moment/point
children.definition: /ˈməʊmənt, pɔɪnt/  anexacttime when something happens, during a longer process or series of events:
examples: thời điểm
▪ the play went well, apart from one embarrassing moment when i dropped a cup.
▪ at several points during the meeting, adler threatened to walk out.
▪ my most special moment with dad was when i was announced as the winner of junior beauty contest.
moment/point in time
▪ at that precise moment in time, binh walked in.

children.name: when you ask what time it is
ask (sb) the time
children.definition: ask (somebody) the time/ask (somebody) what timeit is /ˌɑːsk somebody ðə ˈtaɪm, ˌɑːsk somebody wɒt ˈtaɪm ɪt ɪzǁˌæsk-/  to ask someone to tell you the time:
examples: ▪ she was walking home near colbayns school when a man approached her and asked her the time.
▪ she was distracted for a moment by someone asking the time.
▪ go and ask dad what time it is.
▪ if you’ve got a watch, why are you asking what time it is?

children.name: what time is it?
children.definition: alsowhat’s the time?british /wɒt ˈtaɪm ɪz ɪt, ˌwɒts ðə ˈtaɪm/ spoken say this to ask someone you are with to tell you the time:
examples: ▪ ‘what time is it?’ ‘just after four o'clock.’
▪ what’s the time? is it after 10?

children.name: have you got the time?
children.definition: british /do you have the time? american /ˌhæv juː gɒt ðə ˈtaɪmǁ-gɑːt-, duː juː ˌhæv ðə ˈtaɪm/ spoken say this to ask someone the time, when you do not know whether they have a watch:
examples: ▪ sorry to trouble you, but do you have the time?
have the right time
▪ does anyone have the right time here?
have the time on you british
▪ excuse me! have you got the time on you please?

children.name: ways of saying what time it is
o'clock
children.definition: /əˈklɒkǁəˈklɑːk/  use this when the time is exactly a particular hour:
examples: ▪ it’s 5 o'clock.
▪ it’s exactly 10 o'clock.

children.name: just before/after
children.definition: alsojustgonebritish /ˈdʒʌst bɪfɔːʳ, ɑːftəʳǁ-æf-, ˈdʒʌst gɒnǁ-gɔːn/  use this when the time is a little before or after a particular hour:
examples: ▪ it’s just before 6.
▪ it’s just after 10 o'clock.
▪ it’s just gone midnight. just after

children.name: to
children.definition: alsoofamerican /tuː, ɒv/  use this to say that the time is a particular number of minutes before a particular hour:
examples: ▪ it’s ten to six.
▪ it doesn’t get dark until about twenty to ten.
▪ it’s a quarter of eleven.
▪ joe, by the ten of eight you’re going upstairs and that’s only about a half hour from now.

children.name: past
children.definition: alsoafteramerican /pɑːstǁpæst, ˈɑːftəʳǁˈæf-/ use this to say that the time is a particular number of minutes after a particular hour:
examples: ▪ it’s quarter past four.
▪ it’s ten after five.
▪ it’s quarter after eight, and laurie’s showing up at nine.
▪ it’s half past two.

children.name: it’s getting on for
children.definition: /ɪts ˌgetɪŋ ˈɒn fɔːʳ/ british use this to say that it is almost a particular time, especially when you are guessing what time it might be:
examples: ▪ it’s getting on for five o'clock.
▪ i should think it’s getting on for ten by now.

children.name: bang/dead on
children.definition: /ˈbæŋ, ˈded ɒn/  britishinformaluse this to say that it is exactly a particular time:
examples: ▪ ‘what time is it?’ ‘bang on midnight.’
▪ i make it dead on half past by my watch.
▪ we finished bang on eight, and we were back home by nine.

children.name: what hour, day etc st happens
time
children.definition: /taɪm/  theparticularminuteorhourof the day when something is planned to happen, or the particularminuteorhourthat it happened in thepast:
examples: giờ ( mấy giờ mấy phút )
the time of something
▪ could i have the times of the trains to birmingham please?
▪ this leaflet lists the dates and times of all the concerts.
▪ the police are still trying to establish the exact time of her death.
what time?
▪ what time did you see the man leave the bus station?
▪ what time do you usually start in the mornings?
▪ what time is the news on?
departure/arrival timethe time when a train, plane, etc leaves or arrives : thời gian khởi hành / đến
▪ the departure times are posted on our website.
▪ the plane’s estimated arrival time is 19:45.
opening/closing timethe time when a shop, office etc opens or closes : giờ mở cửa, giờ đóng cửa ( bắt đầu mở, đóng )
▪ we went into a cafe and sat there until closing time.
▪ i’ve got to get this to the video store by closing time.
opening timesthe normal times when a shop is open : giờ mở cửa
▪ check with the museum for opening times at www.musart.
co.lunchtime/dinnertime etcthe time when you have a meal
▪ robbie! it’s suppertime!
time of year/day etc
▪ the winds are pretty strong at this time of year.
▪ there won’t be much traffic on the roads at this time of night.
by that timeafter a particular hour of the day or night has passed : trước lúc đó
▪ well, most people had gone to bed by that time of night.
▪ she apologized for being late, but by that time i was really annoyed with her.

children.name: date
children.definition: /deɪt/  theday,month, oryearwhen something is planned to happen, or happened:
examples: ngày ( bao gồm ngày, tháng, năm )
▪ do you know the date when the house was built?
▪ we still haven’t received notification of the exam date.
the date(s) of something : ngày ...
▪ give me the dates of the american war of independence.
▪ june 9th is the date of the european elections.
date for : ngày cho
▪ we need to arrange a date for the next meeting.
▪ a date for his release has not yet been agreed.
set a date (for something)choose a particular date : đặt , sắp xếp ngày cho
▪ have they set a date for the wedding yet?
birth date/date of birththe date on which someone was born : ngày sinh
▪ it helps if you provide your birth date and social security number.
▪ could i have your name and your date of birth please?
start datethe date when something begins, especially a job : ngày bắt đầu
▪ i later received confirmation of my new job in a letter indicating the start date.
closing datethe date when a competition, offer etc ends : ngày kết thúc
▪ the closing date for entries is 3 march 2001.
expiry datebritish /expiration dateamerican the date on which something can no longer be used : ngày hết hạn
▪ key in your credit card details, including the expiration date of the card.
▪ are you sure these yoghurts are ok? have you checked the expiry date?
launch/release datethe date when a new product, film, etc is shown to people : ngày ra mắt, ngày phát hành
▪ ‘snow white’ had a december release date to capture the christmas market.

children.name: hours
children.definition: /aʊəʳz/  afixedperiod of time in the day when a particular activity, business etc happens:
examples: giờ
▪ i’d like to return something to your store - what are your hours?
office/opening/business hourswhen an office, shop etc is open : giờ hành chính, mở cửa, làm việc
▪ our telephone hotline is open during regular business hours.
visiting hourswhen you can visit someone in the hospital : giờ thăm viếng
▪ visiting hours are from 2 to 5 every day.
after hoursafter an office, shop etc is closed : sau giờ làm việc, hành chính, mở cửa ....
▪ after hours callers can leave a voicemail message.
out of hoursbritish before or after the usual business hours : ngoài giờ làm việc , hành chính
▪ what was tom doing in the office out of hours?

children.name: hour
children.definition: /aʊəʳ/  aparticularperiod orpointof time during the day or night:
examples: at this hourvery late at night or early in the morning : tại thời điểm này ( quá muộn hay sớm trong ngày )
▪ sir, i’m sorry to bother you at this hour.at some ungodly hour informal very late or very early
▪ we had to get up at some ungodly hour to catch our train.
at all hours
▪ there’s something happening on our street at all hours of the day and night.
lunch/dinner hour
▪ i hate telemarketers who call during the dinner hour.

children.name: timing
children.definition: /ˈtaɪmɪŋ/  a word meaning the time, day, or date that something is planned to happen, used especially when you areconsideringhowsuitablethis is:
examples: thời gian ( thích hợp hay ko )
timing of
▪ the voter survey is crucial to the timing of the election.

children.name: at
children.definition: /ət, strong æt/  use this withhoursandminutesof the day, special holidays, or thebeginningorendof a period of time:
examples: at six o'clock/half-past four/midnight/lunchtime etc
▪ he starts work at 10, and finishes at 6:30.
▪ would you like to go to the sandwich bar at lunchtime?
▪ i have a hospital appointment at 9.00 am.
at christmas/easter/new year
▪ we get a week’s holiday at easter.
▪ what are you doing at christmas?
at the end/beginning/start (of something)
▪ frank joined the navy at the beginning of the war.
▪ we get paid at the end of the week.
▪ the students all do a short test at the start of term.

children.name: on
children.definition: /ɒnǁɑːn, ɔːn/  use this with particular days:
examples: ▪ the team holds a meeting on the first monday of every month.
▪ i tried to catch him on the last day of term, but he’d already left.
on monday/tuesday night/friday evening etc
▪ we’re going out for dinner on friday.
▪ are you doing anything special on saturday night?
on august 12th/march 2nd etc
▪ she was born on may 12, 1913.
▪ the course starts on 14 october.
on my birthday/their wedding day/valentine’s day etc
▪ did you call dad on father’s day?
▪ aren’t you coming here on christmas day?
on thursdays/fridays etcalsoon a thursday/friday etcbritish every thursday, friday etc
▪ her husband takes her shopping on a saturday to asda.
▪ we always go to the pub on fridays.

children.name: in
children.definition: /ɪn/  use this with parts of the day, particular years, or particular months, and seasons of the year:
examples: in the morning/afternoon/evening
▪ i’m usually too tired to cook a meal in the evening.
▪ we didn’t get to bed until 3 o'clock in the morning.
first thing in the morningvery early in the morning
▪ i want to be ready to leave first thing in the morning.
▪ in 2004, the olympic games will be held in athens.
in the fifties/sixties/1990s etc from 1950 to 1959, 1960 to 1969 etc
▪ he did a lot of abstract art in the sixties, but he’s moved on since then.
in january/february/the autumn etc
▪ i came to england in the summer of 1995.
▪ the series returns in the autumn.
▪ ‘how old is philip now?’ ‘he’s four in december’.

children.name: ago
children.definition: /əˈgəʊ/  use this to say how far back in the past something happened:
examples: trước
5 minutes/an hour/100 years etc ago
▪ michael left the office 20 minutes ago.
▪ ‘when did you hurt your back?’ ‘about a fortnight ago.’
▪ my daughter was married just over a year ago.
a long time ago
▪ i met your father once, a long time ago.
a short time ago/a little while ago
▪ did you see that program about genetics that was on a little while ago?
a minute/moment ago
▪ i had my keys a minute ago, and now i can’t find them.
not so long agoused to say that something was quite a short time ago
▪ we went down to see a show in london not so long ago.
how long ago?used to ask how far back in the past something happened
▪ how long ago was that, dad?
▪ how long ago did you buy the computer?

children.name: on/at the stroke of
children.definition: /ɒn, ət ðə ˈstrəʊk ɒv/  atexactlya particular time and not any earlier or later:
examples: đúng
▪ on the stroke of midnight, the british flag was lowered for the last time over delhi.
▪ the judge entered the courtroom at the stroke of nine.
